title: Genesis of the Daleks
dialogue_triumphs: The Doctor asks Davros, 'If you created a virus in your laboratory, something contagious and infectious, that killed on contact… would you use it?' Davros: 'The only living thing. A microscopic organism reigning supreme… To hold in my hand a capsule that contained such power. To know that life and death on such a scale was my choice… To know that the tiny pressure of my thumb, enough to break the glass, would end everything. Yes, I would do it. That power would set me up above the gods! And through the Daleks I shall have that power!'

The Doctor, with the future of the Daleks in his hands: 'If someone who knew the future pointed out a child to you and told you that the child would grow up… to be a ruthless dictator who would destroy millions of lives, could you then kill that child?… Do I have that right?'
goofs: Sarah has a premonition of 'Revenge of the Cybermen' (she mentions the beacon, but Nerva was not a beacon in that story).
At the end of episode two, Sarah falls outside the gantry: in episode three's resolution, she falls onto a platform inside it.
In episode three, between the Doctor looking up at the rocket and the soldier crawling to the switch, there is a single frame of the Doctor's back, the result of sloppy editing.
The Doctor seems magically to recover his coat between episodes one and six.

continuity_notes.name: Time Lords
continuity_notes.description: An advanced race capable of time travel, who intercept the TARDIS crew and send the Doctor on a mission.
continuity_notes.current_status: Interfering with history by sending the Doctor to alter the Daleks' creation.

continuity_notes.name: Daleks
continuity_notes.description: Genetically engineered creatures created by Davros, destined to become a major threat to the universe.
continuity_notes.current_status: In the process of being created by Davros.

continuity_notes.name: Davros
continuity_notes.description: The creator of the Daleks, a brilliant but ruthless scientist.
continuity_notes.current_status: Conducting experiments to create the Daleks.

continuity_notes.name: Time Ring
continuity_notes.description: A device given to the Doctor by the Time Lords to return to his TARDIS.

technobabble: The Doctor's pocket contains 'an etheric beam locator, it's also useful for detecting ion-charged emissions'
roots: Terry Nation's The Avengers episodes 'Invasion of the Earthmen' and 'Legacy of Death'
William L. Shirer's The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich

locations.name: Skaro
locations.description: Home planet of the Daleks, Thals, and Kaleds, devastated by a thousand-year war.
locations.current_status: Ravaged by war between the Kaleds and the Thals.

future_history: The episode establishes a potential future where the Daleks become the supreme power in the Universe, which the Time Lords seek to prevent.
untold_adventures: The Doctor mentions a Dalek invasion of Mars failing due to a virus.
additional_notes: This story significantly alters the established history of the Daleks, creating a new timeline where Davros plays a crucial role in their development.
bottom_line: 'Genesis of the Daleks' includes, in Davros, possibly the ultimate Doctor Who villain.
